newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela bolivar ends softer at 481.50/482.50/dlr.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela bolivar ends softer at 481.50/482.50/dlr.

text.p: The Venezuelan bolivar closed softer at 481.50/482.50 per dollar after the Central Bank mostly stayed away from a quiet session and benchmark six month TEM bill yields fell 123 basis points to 17.48 percent in Wednesday's auction, traders said.
"The Central Bank came in, but only a little. It gave a few small touches to keep the market calm. But few dollars were needed," said one trader.

Venezuela's foreign exchange market is unusual in that the Central Bank is its largest single supplier of dollars, which blurs the difference between the Central Bank supplying liquidity and intervening.
Local business chamber Conindustria president Pedro Carmona also voiced concern Thursday that the bolivar was increasingly over-valued.

"We calculate the bolivar is now around ten percent over- valued, a tolerable level ... but that could more than double by year end," Carmona told reporters after presenting Conindustria's first quarter of 1997 business confidence survey.
Venezuela continues to pursue an inflation-fighting strong bolivar policy, where the currency ostensibly floats between slowly depreciating bands set by Central Bank intervention.
Critics say the policy has left the bolivar increasingly over-valued with the exchange rate little-changed since price and currency controls were removed in April last year.
